prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS13679
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is one of the distant bright galaxies with redshift confirmed from our ESO large program in the COSMOS CANDELS field. We aim to detect the [CII]158 micron line emission and possibly the thermal dust continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will exploit the lowest spectral resolution of the 3840 channels set up which is adequate for our purpose of ultimately determining the redshifts, and has the flexibility of rebinning to the most adequate bin size in terms of a tradeoff between S/N and spectral sampling. At the same time this gives the highest continuum sensitivity amongst the configurations
We are only aiming at detecting [CII] line without spatially resolving it

Requested sensitivity: in all our estimates we assume for the [CII] line a width of 100 km/s which is approximately the average for star forming galaxies at z=5.5 observed by Capak et al. (2015)
For all targets we require to reach a limit of Log(L(CII)=7.5 in order to firmly establish in case of non detection, that the z=7 sources do not follow the same CII- SFR relation as metal poor star forming galaxies at low redshift (de Looze et al. 2014) and up to z=6 (Capak et al. 2015, Willot et al. 2015). For source COSMOS13679 at z=7.145 this limit is reached in 1.3 hours
We also estimate what would be the S/N achieved on the [CII] line in case of no evolution of the [CII]- SFR relation We conservatively assume the lower limit of SFR from the observed UV continuum emission (not corrected for dust absorption) which is 24 Msol/yr. We then convert this into a [CII] luminosity by assuming the calibration of Sargysan et al. (2012) yielding a line flux of 2.35 mJy. Assuming a line width of 100 km/s and a spectral binning of 50 km/s we will detect [CII] line with a S/N=9 per bin, which is more than sufficient for our scientific aims.
We recall that this is a lower limit since the intrinsic SFR of the object is probably higher than what inferred by UV continuum alone.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDS1920
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is one of the distant bright galaxies with redshift confirmed from our ESO large program and part of a close triplet in the UDS field. We aim to detect the [CII]158 micron line emission and possibly the thermal dust continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will exploit the lowest spectral resolution of the 3840 channels set up which is adequate for our purpose of ultimately determining the redshifts, and has the flexibility of rebinning to the most adequate bin size in terms of a tradeoff between S/N and spectral sampling. At the same time this gives the highest continuum sensitivity amongst the configurations
We are only aiming at detecting [CII] line without spatially resolving it

Requested sensitivity: in all our estimates we assume for the [CII] line a width of 100 km/s which is approximately the average for star forming galaxies at z=5.5 observed by Capak et al. (2015)
For all targets we require to reach a limit of Log(L(CII)=7.5 in order to firmly establish in case of non detection, that the z=7 sources do not follow the same CII- SFR relation as metal poor star forming galaxies at low redshift (de Looze et al. 2014) and up to z=6 (Capak et al. 2015, Willot et al. 2015). For source UDS1920 at z=6.565 this limit is reached in 1.0 hours
We also estimate what would be the S/N achieved on the [CII] line in case of no evolution of the [CII]- SFR relation We conservatively assume the lower limit of SFR from the observed UV continuum emission (not corrected for dust absorption) which is 16 Msol/yr. We then convert this into a [CII] luminosity by assuming the calibration of Sargysan et al. (2012) yielding a line flux of 1.80 mJy. Assuming a line width of 100 km/s and a spectral binning of 50 km/s we will detect [CII] line with a S/N=6 per bin, which is more than sufficient for our scientific aims.
We recall that this is a lower limit since the intrinsic SFR of the object is probably higher than what inferred by UV continuum alone.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will exploit the lowest spectral resolution of the 3840 channels set up which is adequate for our purpose of ultimately determining the redshifts, and has the flexibility of rebinning to the most adequate bin size in terms of a tradeoff between S/N and spectral sampling. We are only aiming at detecting [CII] line without spatially resolving it

For all targets we require to reach a limit of Log(L(CII)=7.5 in order to firmly establish in case of non detection, that the z=7 sources do not follow the same CII- SFR relation as metal poor star forming galaxies at low redshift (de Looze et al. 2014) and up to z=6 (Capak et al. 2015, Willot et al. 2015). We also estimate what would be the S/N achieved on the [CII] line in case of no evolution of the [CII]- SFR relation We conservatively assume the lower limit of SFR from the observed UV continuum emission (not corrected for dust absorption) which is 29.7 Msol/yr. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NTTDF6345
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is one of the distant bright galaxies with redshift confirmed from our ESO observations. We aim to detect the [CII]158 micron line emission and possibly the thermal dust continuum Observations for this galaxy were already approved (with priority C) in Cycle 2 but have not been executed

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will exploit the lowest spectral resolution of the 3840 channels set up which is adequate for our purpose of ultimately determining the redshifts, and has the flexibility of rebinning to the most adequate bin size in terms of a tradeoff between S/N and spectral sampling. At the same time this gives the highest continuum sensitivity amongst the configurations
We are only aiming at detecting [CII] line without spatially resolving it

Requested sensitivity: in all our estimates we assume for the [CII] line a width of 100 km/s which is approximately the average for star forming galaxies at z=5.5 observed by Capak et al. (2015).
For all targets we require to reach a limit of Log(L(CII)=7.5 in order to firmly establish in case of non detection, that the z=7 sources do not follow the same CII- SFR relation as metal poor star forming galaxies at low redshift (de Looze et al. 2014) and up to z=6 (Capak et al. 2015, Willot et al. 2015). For source NTTDF6345 at z=6.701 this limit is reached in 1.03 hours
We also estimate what would be the S/N achieved on the [CII] line in case of no evolution of the [CII]- SFR relation We conservatively assume the lower limit of SFR from the observed UV continuum emission (not corrected for dust absorption) which is 19.4 Msol/yr. We then convert this into a [CII] luminosity by assuming the calibration of Sargysan et al. (2012) yielding a line flux of 2.11 mJy. Assuming a line width of 100 km/s and a spectral binning of 50 km/s we will detect [CII] line with a S/N=8 per bin, which is more than sufficient for our scientific aims.
We recall that this is a lower limit since the intrinsic SFR of the object is probably higher than what inferred by UV continuum alone.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Recent exiting results have shown that up to z=6 (just a billion years after the Big Bang) star forming galaxies have [CII] emission comparable to the low redshift metal poor galaxies; however at earlier epochs (z=7) the sceario is much more confused, with some indications that the [CII] emission from star forming galaxies is considerably below the epectation for a given SFR. Understanding how the properties of primeval galaxies evolve at these early epochs is crucial, since they are probably the key players in the process of reionization
We propose to use ALMA to detect and map [CII]158 micron line in a representative sample of bright galaxies in the reionization epoch, for which we have obtained accurate redshifts from the Lyalpha emission line. These galaxies are the brightest is a new sample of high redshift galaxies that we observed with FORS2 as part of an ongoing ESO Large program. Our observations will be deep enough to either detect unambigously the [CII] line, or to set deep lower limits such that we will be able to conclude with no doubts that the properties of galaxies have evolved considerably in the time between z=7 and z=6.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
